$AMD broke below $210 and is down over 13% post-earnings

$AMZN and OpenAI are reportedly exploring a deal to build custom AI models for Amazon‚Äôs products which would deepen OpenAI‚Äôs use of AWS.

As models commoditize, the real value accrues to AWS as the infrastructure layer by capturing more workloads, lock-in & enterprise adoption.
Owning software in 2026 while the S&P 500 is down less than 1% from ATHs
$APP down ~40% so far in 2026

$AMZN AWS CEO Matt Garman said demand is so strong that AWS has never retired an $NVDA A100 GPU despite the chip being ~6 years old.

Instead of each generation replacing the last, every new GPU generation stacks on top because demand exceeds total supply across all generations.

$T has partnered with $AMZN LEO satellite unit and AWS to modernize its network and U.S. connectivity. 

The collaboration brings hybrid cloud, AI-driven automation, expanded fiber and LEO broadband to support large-scale cloud and AI workloads.

$NVDA CEO Jensen Huang said the market is wrong to think AI will replace software companies.

He called the market‚Äôs fear of software displacement ‚Äúillogical‚Äù and said time will prove the thesis wrong.

$UBER Q4 EARNINGS

‚Ä¢ Sales $14.4B vs Est. $14.3B
‚Ä¢ EPS $0.71 vs Est. $0.79
‚Ä¢ Gross Bookings $54.1B vs Est. $53.1B

Q1 Guidance 
‚Ä¢ Gross Bookings $52.7B (+19% YoY)
‚Ä¢ EBITDA $2.42B vs Est. $2.45B

Uber intends to be the largest facilitator of AV trips in the world by 2029.

$GOOGL Gemini & xAI‚Äôs Grok are taking U.S. mobile DAU share from ChatGPT.

Gemini is up from 14.7% to 25.1% YoY while Grok jumped from 1.6% to 15.2%. 

As assistants get bundled into ecosystems, switching costs collapse & distribution starts to matter more than model quality at the margin.
The funniest outcome might also be the most obvious one which is Elon Musk buying back $PYPL for ~$50B and turning it into the default payments rail across the Muskonomy.
$NVDA is close to finalizing a ~$20B investment in OpenAI as part of its latest funding round

$AMD CEO Lisa Su said the data center business is positioned to grow 60%+ annually over the next 3‚Äì5 years driven by record server CPU demand that now makes up more than half of total server revenue.

She added that the MI500 AI accelerator remains on track for a 2027 launch.

In today's Early Look: "Can You Beat Captain Stock Picker?"

When I call someone Captain Stock Picker, a certain type gets offended. People are so sensitive these days, eh? Here's the thing: I'm making fun of my former self!

If I wasn't a great stock picker from 2000-2005, I wouldn't have earned the seed capital to launch my own hedge fund, then Hedgeye. And I definitely wouldn't call myself Captain!

Why have CNBC on at all? I don‚Äôt know how to operate the TV in my office. Has been a blessing. How can I concentrate on clients, emails, the Macro Show, or David Salem‚Äôs missives with sound in the background?

‚ÄúKnowledge and experience are not at odds; the latter is simply another form of the former.‚Äù
- @RyanHoliday

Despite Meta $META guiding for $115-135B in capex for 2025, up nearly $53B YoY at midpoint, CFO Susan Li said Meta will "likely still be constrained through much of 2026 until additional capacity from our own facilities comes online later in the year.‚Äù

$NVDA $AMD $AVGO

Amazon‚Äôs $AMZN investment reportedly could include separate negotiations such as OpenAI expanding its cloud services agreement with AWS, or a commercial agreement with OpenAI to sell enterprise ChatGPT subscriptions to Amazon.

$MSFT $NVDA $ORCL

AMD $AMD reported $10.27 billion in revenue in Q4, up 34% YoY and 11% QoQ, with Data center revenue up 39% YoY to a record $5.4 billion.

Full-year revenue rose 34% to $34.64 billion, with Data center revenue up 32% to $16.6 billion.

$NVDA $AVGO

AI search startup Perplexity signed a three-year, $750 million deal with Microsoft $MSFT to use its Foundry platform to access frontier models from OpenAI, Anthropic and xAI, in its first agreement signed outside of $AMZN AWS.

üì∫ RANGE-BOUND MARKETS, WHY $AAPL IS WORKING, & WHY $AMZN WEAKNESS IS A GIFT

The market continues to behave in a frustrating, stop-driven trading range, particularly in $SPY. 

After an inside day that suggested a potential breakout, the market repeated the same pattern again, bringing the price right back into the middle of the range near $690. This is classic range trading, where false breakdowns and failed breakouts dominate.

$QQQ led to the downside recently, but this weakness appears engineered rather than organic.

$IWM continues to hold key levels, reinforcing the idea that the market is being actively managed within a range rather than breaking down.

Despite the difficulty, there are still opportunities, but traders have to work much harder to find them. This is not a market where broad exposure works easily; it rewards focused, name-by-name execution.

For me, $AAPL stands out as a stock that has improved meaningfully since earnings. $267 is a key level‚Äîif Apple can hold above it, the stock can maintain a constructive, buy-the-dip type sequence where positions can be managed on the long side.

$AMZN is still an earnings play despite a recent down day. It allows traders to buy options more cheaply, improving risk-reward. If earnings and guidance this week are strong and the stock can reclaim the $258 area, upside traction could finally emerge.

Get on my newsletter list for tomorrow's post $GOOGL pre $AMZN update:

t3live.com/rd

üì∫ NO POWER IN #BITCOIN, RANGE TRADING IN $GLD & $SLV

Bitcoin $IBIT continues to show weak momentum, with repeated false breakouts and rejections suggesting downside risk if the $74.5K support fails, opening the door toward the high-$60Ks.

In contrast, gold $GLD and silver $SLV have shifted from short trades into range-bound conditions, where disciplined trade management matters most.

Trim into strength, respect key levels, and avoid aggressive positioning until real momentum returns in precious metals.

$SPX is still holding a very tight upper range. Yesterday the 50day near 6862 was defended and we bounced to close about +15, but these sharp swings inside the range are tough‚Äîno one wants to press risk if that 50day ever gives way with so many tech/software names already damaged.

üö®Software as a Shock: Why Private Credit is imploding. We dive in.

The core issue is that private credit became a major lender to software buyouts just as the economics of many software models began to shift.

But, what is the real, underlying reason though?
See below.
